edge: Slumdog Millionaire is a British drama film set in Mumbai, which follows the story of Jamal Malik from the Juhu slums of Mumbai.
Jamal Malik is the protagonist of the film Slumdog Millionaire, which narrates his story from the Juhu slums of Mumbai.
Dev Patel played the role of Jamal Malik in the film Slumdog Millionaire.
Slumdog Millionaire is a loose adaptation of the novel Q & A by Indian author Vikas Swarup.

While fleeing the riots and taking shelter from the rain, the brothers meet Latika, a girl from their slum
Salim is found by Maman, who trains street children to become beggars. After learning that Maman is blinding the children to make them more effective beggars, Salim escapes with Jamal and Latika.
Salim grabs Latika's hand to help her board a moving train but purposefully lets go as revenge for pulling a prank on him, leaving her to be recaptured by Maman.
Maman raises Latika to become a prostitute after she is unable to keep up with Salim and Jamal while trying to board a moving train.
Salim gets a job with Javed, who is a rival crime lord.
Jamal refuses to leave Salim alone with Latika when he orders him to do so, presumably to sexually assault her.
Maman raises Latika to become a prostitute.
Salim shoots Maman dead when he and his brothers rescue Latika from her captivity.
In 2004, Jamal learns that Salim is a high-ranking lieutenant in Javed's crime organisation. Salim pleads for forgiveness when confronted by Jamal.
In 2004, Jamal confronts Salim who pleads for forgiveness as he is working as a chaiwala in a call centre.
Jamal professes his love for Latika, but she tells him to forget her. Despite the refusal, Jamal promises to wait for her every day at five o'clock at Victoria Terminus.
In a final attempt to reach Latika, Jamal becomes a contestant on Kaun Banega Crorepati, knowing she watches the show.
Attempting to meet him there, Latika is captured by Javed's men, led by Salim. He scars her face while driving away.
The host of Kaun Banega Crorepati, Prem Kumar, attempts to trick Jamal by feeding him the wrong answer to the penultimate question.
After an initial beating, the police inspector listens to Jamal's explanation of how he knew each answer and believes him.
Feeling guilty about his past behaviour, Salim gives Latika his phone and car keys, asking her to forgive him.
After Latika leaves, Salim fills a bathtub with money and sits in it, waiting for Javed to realise what happened.
Jamal is asked the name of the third musketeer, which falls under the category of final question.
Jamal uses his Phone-A-Friend lifeline to call Salim because it is the only phone number he knows.
Latika answers and tells Jamal that she is safe, but does not know the answer. Javed hears Latika on the show and realises that Salim betrayed him.
Salim's men break down the bathroom door.
Javed hears Latika on the show and realises that Salim betrayed him. He and his men break down the bathroom door.
Salim kills Javed before getting shot and killed by the gang.
Jamal guesses and picks the first answer, Aramis. He is correct and wins the grand prize.

In addition to Swarup's original novel Q & A, the film was also inspired by Indian cinema.
In addition to Swarup's original novel Q & A, the film was also inspired by Indian cinema.
Tandan has referred to Slumdog Millionaire as a homage to Hindi cinema, noting that "Simon Beaufoy studied Salim–Javed's kind of cinema minutely."

Boyle has cited the influence of several Bollywood films set in Mumbai. Deewaar (1975), which Boyle described as being "absolutely key to Indian cinema", is a crime film written by Salim-Javed based on the Bombay gangster Haji Mastan, portrayed by Bollywood superstar Amitabh Bachchan, whose autograph Jamal seeks at the beginning of Slumdog Millionaire.
Some scenes of the film "are like Deewaar, the story of two brothers of whom one is completely after money while the younger one is honest and not interested in money." (Anil Kapoor)

Boyle has also stated that the chase in one of the opening scenes of Slumdog Millionaire was based on a "12-minute police chase through the crowded Dharavi slum" in Black Friday (2007), adapted from Hussein Zaidi's book of the same name about the 1993 Bombay bombings.

Black Friday (2007) offered "slick, often mesmerising portrayals of the Mumbai underworld" and displayed realistic "brutality and urban violence." Saurabh Shukla (who plays Constable Srinivas in Slumdog Millionaire) wrote the screenplay for Company (2002).

In August 2007, Warner Independent Pictures acquired the North American rights and Pathé the international rights to distribute Slumdog Millionaire theatrically.

After Warner Independent Pictures was shut down in May 2008, all of its projects, including Slumdog Millionaire, were transferred to Warner Bros., its parent studio. However, Warner Bros. doubted the commercial prospects of Slumdog Millionaire and suggested that it would go straight to DVD without a US theatrical release.

In August 2008, halfway through the month, Warner Bros. entered into a pact with Fox Searchlight Pictures to share distribution of Slumdog Millionaire, with Fox Searchlight buying 50% of Warner Bros.'s interest in the movie and handling US distribution.

Wall Street Journal critic Joe Morgenstern refers to Slumdog Millionaire as, "the film world's first globalised masterpiece."
Ann Hornaday of The Washington Post argues that, "this modern-day 'rags-to-rajah' fable won the audience award at the Toronto International Film Festival earlier this year, and it’s easy to see why."

With its timely setting of a swiftly globalising India and, more specifically, the country’s own version of the Who Wants to Be a Millionaire TV show, combined with timeless melodrama and a hardworking orphan who withstands all manner of setbacks, Slumdog Millionaire plays like Charles Dickens for the 21st century.

node_2: who wants to be a millionaire tv show
edge: With its timely setting of a swiftly globalising India and, more specifically, the country’s own version of the Who Wants to Be a Millionaire TV show, combined with timeless melodrama and a hardworking orphan who withstands all manner of setbacks, Slumdog Millionaire plays like Charles Dickens for the 21st century.

Kenneth Turan of the Los Angeles Times describes the film as "a story of star-crossed romance that the original Warner brothers would have embraced, shamelessly pulling out stops that you wouldn’t think anyone would have the nerve to attempt any more."

Kenneth Turan of the Los Angeles Times describes the film as "a story of star-crossed romance that the original Warner brothers would have embraced, shamelessly pulling out stops that you wouldn’t think anyone would have the nerve to attempt any more."
Roger Ebert of the Chicago Sun-Times gave the film four out of four stars, calling it "a breathless, exciting story, heartbreaking and exhilarating."
Roger Ebert of the Chicago Sun-Times gave the film four out of four stars, calling it "a breathless, exciting story, heartbreaking and exhilarating."

Anthony Lane of the New Yorker described the film as successfully mixing hard-hitting drama with uplifting action and Colm Andrew of the Manx Independent also praised it for combining familiar raw ingredients into a feverish masala.
Anthony Lane of the New Yorker noted that while Boyle and his team believed that Mumbai was as ripe for storytelling as Dickens' London, they chose a sheer fantasy for its emotional momentum.

Anthony Lane of the New Yorker raised the question of whether Boyle got away with assembling his cast for a Bollywood dance number at a railroad station over the closing credits because he had relinquished any claim to realism.

Adoor Gopalakrishnan, one of the most acclaimed film makers in India during the 1980s and 1990s and a five-time Best Director winner of the Indian National Film Awards, lambasted Slumdog Millionaire, calling it in an interview to NDTV: "A very anti-Indian film. All the bad elements of Bombay's commercial cinema are put together and in a very slick way. And it underlines and endorses what the West thinks about us. It is falsehood built upon falsehood. And at every turn is fabricated. At every turn it is built on falsehood."
Fortunately Indians are turning it down.
